nameVariants.name: Holy Angels School of Fort Chipewyan R.C.S. School District No. 57

desc: Holy Angels Mission School was founded in 1874 at the request of the Oblates of Mary Immaculate by the Grey Nuns of Montreal [GNA-000878, p. 4-5]. The School consisted of a one room warehouse that also provided shelter for the two Sisters who arrived to found the school. The first day of classes was on July 28, 1874 with 15 students, two of whom were boarders.
A combined School and Residence was built in 1881.
The original school and residence building was enlarged.
1904-1907: The building was enlarged once more to include two classrooms and four dormitories. No other school construction was undertaken until 1942.
A new school and residence building was constructed in the summer of 1942 and ready for occupancy in the fall of 1943.
As of 1952 Holy Angels School had 5 classrooms.
An additional classroom was added; the small dormitory on the 3rd floor, was turned into a classroom for students in grades 5, 6, 7, 8, and 9.

In 1955, the Government announced plans to build a 6 room federal day school adjacent to and within walking distance of Holy Angels Residence for 120 students attending Holy Angels IRS and for up to 60 students living in homes nearby in Fort Chipewyan. school building was not completed and occupied until January, 1960.

Pending completion of construction, the Government assumed control of the day school inside the residence. On September 1, 1956 the Government created and opened the Chipewyan Indian Day School inside the Residence building and paid 3 the salaries of four teachers. The day school became known as Fort Chipewyan Indian Day School #726.

An additional school entity was established on December 30, 1955 by Roman Catholic Separate School District #57 to provide education for Non-Treaty and Metis Catholic children at Holy Angels IRS. After September 1, 1956, Fort Chipewyan Separate School District #57 operated two classrooms inside Holy Angels School (under rental agreement with the owners of Holy Angels Residence) for local non-Indian and Metis day students. Teachers for the two classrooms were provided by Separate School District #57.

Two new classrooms were constructed at Holy Angels IRS bringing the total to seven. In addition, the school had a games room (recreation room), playground, a new laboratory, a new sewing room, a new 'experiments' room and a new wash house with appliances. Some students received new beds and the upper grades received new desks from the Separate School District.
The Government continued to provide teaching staff for the newly established day school.

Seven classrooms were in operation inside the residence; The Government continued to pay the salaries of 5 teachers and the Fort Chipewyan Roman Catholic Separate School Board [Separate School District #57] paid the salaries of two teachers.

December 15, 1959 – Government assumed possession of day school building. December 29, 1959 - Staff, students and materials began moving into the new day school building that housed 6 classrooms. Two Grade 1 classrooms remained in operation inside Holy Angels Residence. The Government provided 6 teachers and Fort Chipewyan RC Separate School District #57 provided two teachers. Discussions were in progress to amalgamate the Separate School with the federal school.
January 4, 1960 - First day of classes inside the new Fort Chipewyan day school. A fire in the new day school building auditorium on April 8, 1960 caused smoke and heat damage to classrooms.

The Fort Chipewyan RC Separate School District #57 rented and occupied two classrooms inside Holy Angels Residence until June 30 1961. The Fort Chipewyan RC Separate School and the Fort Chipewyan Indian Day School amalgamated on September 1, 1961; by Sept. 28, 1961 all classes were taught in the day school building and the residence remained a hostel facility. New classrooms were created in the day school by using space in the recreation room, boys’ workshop and nursing room.

Fort Chipewyan Indian Day School remained under federal government administration until June 30, 1963. On July 1, 1963, the management of the day school was transferred to the Province of Alberta under the Northland School Division.
Fort Chipewyan Day School is renamed Bishop Piche School; the earliest document found that refers to Fort Chipewyan Day School as Bishop Piche School is dated June 23, 1964.

The Province of Alberta through Northland School Division continued to operate the day school until August 30, 1971, when responsibility for the management of the day school reverted back to the federal government.

The official closing date of Holy Angels Residence was June 30, 1974. The last of the student residents departed on June 22, 1974. Three of the lay staff members were employed until July 14, 1974, and six religious staff until July 31, 1974 for the purpose of closing down the premises.

writtenAgreements.desc: The only written agreement respecting the operation of Holy Angels IRS that has been located is the 1911 Agreement for the operation of Holy Angels IRS between His Majesty the King and the Rt. Rev. Emile Grouard, O.M.I., Bishop of Athabaska.

Memorandum and copies of Cost Sharing Agreement between Roman Catholic Fort Chipewyan Separate School District #57 and Canada. The substance of the agreements between Canada and the RCCSD was a cost sharing formula whereby the Catholic School Board would pay a proportional share of operating costs based on numbers of non-Indian students admitted at their request, while the remainder of school operating expenses including infrastructure costs would be funded by Canada.

Agreement for the Operation of a School between Canada and Northland School Division No. 61 to provide Indian pupils with classroom accommodation and instruction at Divisional schools including Fort Chipewyan/

Memorandum of Understanding between Northland School Division No. 61 and Fort Chipewyan Roman Catholic Separate School District No. 57 to '…accept for enrolment in the school known as Holy Angels School and in such other school or schools as may be built adjacent to the Holy Angels School in the Fort Chipewyan Roman Catholic Separate School District No 57…'

Correspondence has been located that refers to Liaison Agreements between the Government and the Oblate Indian-Eskimo Council for Holy Angels IRS after April 1, 1969. However, the agreements themselves have not been located.

Copy of Agreement for transfer of operation of Bishop Piche School from Northland School Division back to Canada; under this agreement Canada will provide school accommodation for all students and cover all operating costs; the Northland School Division will pay to Canada a per capita share of school operating expenses based on numbers of students provided by the Province of Alberta and shall AMake interim payments quarterly or as mutually agreed to by parties concerned, subject to settlement of the share of operating costs as determined in sub-paragraph (a) at the end of each fiscal year upon receipt of the annual financial statement for Bishop Piche school.'; Canada will undertake capital expenditures and make repairs; any building programs would be undertaken by special agreement between the Canada and the province.

additionalInformation.notes: Between 1874 and 1923, 59 deaths were recorded at the school out of a registered total of 552 pupils.
The control of tuberculosis at the school was a health issue in 1938 due to the lack of facilities for carrying out segregation of tubercular pupils at the school.
A flu epidemic throughout the north also affected children at Fort Chipewyan IRS; classrooms were closed.

After 1960 school buildings and accommodation at Holy Angels IRS were judged to be aged and inadequate for the number of boarders present. Of concern were unsanitary conditions and inadequate sleeping, eating, washing and dishwashing facilities due to overcrowding.
Lake water from Lake Athabaska was judged by school staff to be unsafe for use as drinking water by school children at Holy Angels IRS.

Health authorities recommended that 'Lake Athabaska be discontinued as a source of drinking water for the school during the summer months as the amount of local pollution to which it is subjected renders it unsafe for this purpose unless it is either boiled or chlorinated and filtered as well.'
As of 1957 students still used outside latrines and staff used an antiquated sewage disposal that was judged to be in unsanitary condition.
Tests of the water supply in 1962 and 1964 showed high nitrate and ammonia content in wells in Fort Chipewyan, apparently indicative of ongoing sewage pollution.
In 1961 a Dietician’s Report identified the lack of vitamin C in diets of children at Fort Chipewyan IRS and below standard levels of sanitation as potential health risks.

In 1965 a Dietician’s Report Re: Food Service conditions at Holy Angels IRS recommended that Afruit be served twice daily....'Also recommended is a source high in Vitamin C. This may be the citrus fruits or their juices, vitamin enriched apple juice, tomatoes juice, and vitamin enriched juice crystals, raw cabbage, raw turnips...'
The first recorded School Inspection located up to this time was in 1911 by Indian Affairs Inspector H.A. Conroy.
The earliest available reference to a provincial inspection of Holy Angels IRS is a letter of enquiry from DIA to the Alberta Minister of Education.
An Inspection Report re buildings and school owned by Church.
A Sanitation Report listed the buildings at Holy Angels IRS.
Letter from DIA Superintendent of Education to Superintendent of Schools, Province of Alberta with request to inspect Indian Schools including Holy Angels.
Letter from DIA Superintendent of Education to Superintendent of Schools, Province of Alberta with request to inspect Indian Schools including Holy Angels.
The first recorded Provincial Inspections of Holy Angels IRS, that have been located up to this time, were in 1952.
Fire damaged part of the gymnasium and shop areas of school on April 8-9, 1960, but the classroom facilities could still be used.
A fire in the boiler room of the Day School, February 2nd, 1965, caused some damage to heating equipment.
Bishop Piche Day School was destroyed by an arson fire on July 19, 1981. Sixteen portable classrooms were brought in by barge to replace the destroyed facilities.
